results.title: Animation on film
results.brief_description: An introduction to the principles and techniques of film animation, the equipment needed - the rostrum, animation bench, and mounting of the camera are discussed. The planning of animation, and the care and accuracy needed throughout all stages are shown in detail. Roland Kemp is animation advisor.

results.title: Animals of the rocky shore
results.creator_credit: W. Hugh Baddeley and Hugh Baddeley Productions
results.brief_description: This film presents creatures of the rocky shore. Close-ups of crabs are shown, revealing the complexity of the mouth parts. In deeper water mullet, pollack and bass are shown swimming. An egg-case is removed from a dogfish and the developing embryo is shown.

results.title: Animals in winter
results.creator_credit: Heinz Sielmann and Heinz Sielmann Productions
results.brief_description: The behaviour in winter of squirrels, hamsters, insects, frogs, butterflies and other creatures, showing how they cope with the rigours of cold and the shortage of food in order to survive until the spring. Intended for primary and secondary schools

results.title: Animal migration
results.brief_description: Describes the migratory patterns of animals such as the mountain sheep, monarch butterfly, whale, elephant seal, salmon and arctic tern. Examines the reasons for animals migrating, the ways in which they navigate, and the scientific methods used to study migration. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Angel exit. Sekala has to die
results.creator_credit: Vladimir Michalek, Jaroslav Boucek and BUC Film
results.brief_description: Two very different films from Czechoslovakian filmmaker Vladimir Michalek. “Angel exit” is a gritty urban drama set in a lower class milieu, an outer suburb of Prague. Mikes is a young man with a criminal record and a history of drug abuse whose girlfriend implores him to change so they may make a life together. Lukas, Mikes best friend and Kaja, another young addict, encourage Lukas to continue using. The three of them are unable to forge an existence beyond the realms of petty crime, perpetual scoring and getting high. Filmed on digital, “Angel exit” utilises the style of cinema verite, and has a pallid colour scheme that reflects the futility of its angry and abusive protagonists. “Sekala has to die” is a World War II period drama, set in a rural Czech village where two interlopers - Sekala and Zaprdek, threaten the local community. Sekala is the half brother of Oberva, a highly regarded member of the town, who is respected by their father. When Sekala’s demands press the tolerance of the locals a young blacksmith is chosen to execute Sekala and rid them of his menace. Beautifully photographed, “Sekala has to die” is a moral tale, seeped in the typical golden tones of European art house cinema.

results.title: And they named it Holland
results.creator_credit: Gerard J. Raucamp and Carillon Films
results.brief_description: Provides aerial views of Holland, without commentary. Illustrates the variety of environment contrasting old and new, urban and rural, highlighting the diversity of life in a small and densely populated country.

results.title: And then there were four
results.creator_credit: Frank Strayer, Roland Reed and Roland Reed Productions
results.brief_description: Hollywood actor, James Stewart, narrates the story of five people leaving for work in the morning. None of these people are reckless drivers, but we know in advance that one of them will die on the road that day. When one fails to return at evening, we know he is the victim of a road accident. This film is a dramatic lesson in traffic law observance. An epilogue provides relevance to Australian road safety statistics for the time.

results.title: And the moon dances = Bulan terusuk ilalang
results.creator_credit: Garin Nugroho, PT Genta Nusa Dwipantara and S E T Film Workshop
results.brief_description: Shot in Solo, director Garin Nugroho’s hometown, ‘And the Moon Dances’ is a rich visual and aural feast of feudal Javanese culture. Ilalang, a young music student, comes to Solo for an attachment at the local dance and culture school. This is where he meets Bulan, a girl who has just returned from America. However, the love between them remains unrequited as Ilalang is trying to deal with the trauma he suffered in childhood at the hands of his father. The paradox of the Javanese culture is the central theme of this film. To quote from director Nugroho, the Javanese culture ‘could be beautiful and soft at one time and violent the next’. Technically, this film surpasses its predecessors. The colours are rich and the sound of the Gamelan, omnipresent throughout the film, superbly showcased. This film received the FIPRESCI Award at the 1996 Berlin International Film Festival. Cast includes Ratna Paquita, Wiwiek Handawiyah, Ki Sutarman. In Bahasa Indonesia with English subtitles.
